title: How to use an Oxford comma correctly - Quora

response.answer_text: This sentence makes you a deeply upsetting Messiah, albeit one who could sell out stadiums: I’d like to thank my parents, Taylor Swift and God. This sentence lists three separate elements, although if the order of importance is ascending, it’s still not clear why you want to thank Taylor Swift more vigorously than your parents — but that’s your problem, not the sentence’s: I’d like to thank my parents, Taylor Swift, and God. There is a famous example that purports to be similar, using the example of Nelson Mandela, an 800-year-old demigod, and a dildo collector. However, this blog post explains why merely adding the Oxford comma wouldn’t solve the problem, and the writer would probably want to reverse the order of the elements anyway.

The “Oxford Comma” (something I always use because it eliminates ambiguity) is the “extra” comma added before the penultimate item in a list of three or more items. “John, Mary and Paul went to the concert together”. (No Oxford comma). “John, Mary, and Paul went to the concert together” (with Oxford comma). In one of the other answers, Gwyn McVay offers the example of the ambiguity that can arise by not using the Oxford comma: “I’d like to thank my parents, Taylor Swift and God.” Not using it in the above sentence means that you could legitimately read the sentence as meaning that your parents were Taylor Swift and God (though imaging Taylor Swift as the Virgin Mary boggles the mind…).
